channel.title: Home on Rick Wysocki
channel.description: Recent content in Home on Rick Wysocki

item.title: Test Summary
item.description: Here is a little bit of text.

item.title: Less Nerd, More Punk
item.description: We’ve ceded too much ground to nerds. We need to bring back a digital-punk ethos.

item.title: Genre’s Normative Function
item.description: Brief and wandering thoughts on genre.

item.title: Two Books (and Bookwyrm)
item.description: Thoughts on books I’ve read so far this year.

item.title: Link Roundup: January 27, 2025
item.description: Two articles on how we hide unethical behavior as “apps” and the need to dependencize everything.

item.title: Link Roundup: January 20, 2025
item.description: The old Internet was good. Or, at least, less bad.

item.title: 2024 Review: The Movies
item.description: Visualizations of, and thoughts on, my year watching movies.

item.title: 2024 Review: The Books
item.description: A collection of thoughts on the books I read this year.

item.title: Link Roundup: November 4, 2024
item.description: Fritz Lang on his film M and a tutorial for HTML-based resumes.

item.title: Content Management Pedagogy
item.description: Learning management systems have turned teachers into content managers. That’s bad.

item.title: Joker: Folie à Deux
item.description: Genre bending is played out. It just is.

item.title: Link Roundup: October 8, 2024
item.description: Book reviews and article writeups for the week.

item.title: The Ignorant Schoolmaster: Five Lessons in Intellectual Emancipation (A Review)
item.description: A review of Jacques Rancière’s The Ignorant Schoolmaster and a reflection on his critique of rhetoric.

item.title: Cannon Shot Epistemology
item.description: Maybe we can’t shouldn’t base our thinking on what AI is now. Maybe we should think harder about what it could become.

item.title: I Don't Know What to Do About AI, and Neither Do You
item.description: This is a rant.

item.title: Bookish Thoughts
item.description: Brief notes on good books I’ve read this year.

item.title: Link Roundup: September 9, 2024
item.description: A link roundup of articles and thoughts on practices of reading, why ChatGPT is still extraordinarily limited at writing, and the “missing questions” in our conversations about the future.

item.title: Link Roundup: September 2, 2024
item.description: A strange combination of a 1998 interview with Paul Virilio and a blog post about ways to make better decisions.

item.title: Link Roundup: August 26, 2024
item.description: A link roundup up full of technical skepticism and the benefits of cutting back.

item.title: Stay on the Bus: or, Optimization is a Dirty Word
item.description: A grammar-based argument about why seeking optimizations might just be a big waste of time.

item.title: Link Roundup: August 19, 2024
item.description: An article on the (lack of) regulation of solar power.

item.title: Link Roundup: August 12, 2024
item.description: This week’s link roundup includes the unique combination of an article on the most-cited authors in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy and advice on non-scalable activities for startups.

item.title: Link Roundup: August 5, 2024
item.description: This week’s articles emphasize the importance of archival work and offer an interesting writing-process heuristic.

item.title: Link Roundup: July 29, 2024
item.description: This week’s articles touch on how complexity emerges from simple systems.

item.title: Link Roundup: July 22, 2024
item.description: This week’s roundup has articles on cognitive empathy, kimchi, and technical writing workflows. All the best things!

item.title: Link Roundup: July 15, 2024
item.description: A link roundup including an article on ways that organizations can set up technical writers to be successful and another offering a waterfall of advice for reflective self-management over a career.

item.title: Link Roundup: July 7, 2024
item.description: This week I’ve included articles on mindfulness in technical writing, friction in software development, and the concerning environmental implications of Hurricane Beryl.

item.title: Article Review: Trust in Artificial Intelligence
item.description: This post discusses a meta-analysis of studies related to trust in AI systems. I consider its implications for how AI might continue to be taken up in work contexts.

item.title: Link Roundup: July 1, 2024
item.description: A link roundup including my thoughts on Steven Peck’s A Short Stay in Hell, storytelling for UX design, and the importance of document version control.

item.title: Link Roundup: June 24, 2024
item.description: Some links and thoughts on the relationship between AI and environmental concerns and on action titles as a tool for slide design.

item.title: Text and Meaning in A Short Stay in Hell
item.description: Some thoughts on text and meaning in Steven Peck’s Novella, A Short Stay in Hell.

item.title: Link Roundup: June 17, 2024
item.description: Some interesting content I read this week.

item.title: Link Roundup: June 10, 2024
item.description: A link roundup on AI development.

item.title: Writing Feedback with TextExpander
item.description: This post details how I use TextExpander to offer high-quality feedback to my students in an organized and efficient manner.

item.title: Kuura Cola
item.description: An introduction to my obsession and notes on a tasty and very straightforward ripe puer tea.

item.title: Some Updates
item.description: With a lot going on in my life (positively), I’ve been a bit slow on writing posts here. This week, though, I’ve been doing some work around the site and figured I’d note a few updates.

item.title: Bulang Huang Chen Hao (2018)
item.description: Liquid Proust Drank on April 3, rainy day evening session. The leaves broke up really nice. I used 10 grams in 100 ml gaiwan to use up some remaining leaves in the sample. Flash steeps. Young puer sour smell on the wet leaves. Tasted somewhere between a slightly aged and young puer. Could taste the “grandma’s house” notes behind the astringency, similar to Love Forever. Not too think and not too light of a mouthfeel.

item.title: Learning Asciidoc
item.description: I learned AsciiDoc.

item.title: Conditional Image Layouts in Hugo
item.description: This post describes how to write conditional image layouts using Go and HTML for a Hugo site.

item.title: Ted Nelson's Evolutionary List File and Information Management
item.description: In 1965, Ted Nelson theorized the Evolutionary List File and offered clear insights into the relationship between technology and creativity that are still relevant today.

item.title: Little Ghost Theme
item.description: I just put up a Hugo Theme on Github.

item.title: New Site (and Birthday Post)
item.description: I’ve got a new site put together. And a quick review of the year.

item.description: So, I’m learning Hugo.

item.title: Covid - Day Four
item.description: Today will be a shorter post. Rather than write, I spent most of the day a) submitting grades and b) working on a new track.

item.title: Covid - Day Three
item.description: Day three has been alright so far. Last night, again, my only issue sleeping was my wrecked throat. A bought me some chloraseptic today; I imagine that will help tonight.

item.title: Covid - Day Two
item.description: My second day of Covid. The good news-A tested this morning and so far continues to come up negative. The bad news-I feel like butt.

item.title: Covid - Day One
item.description: I made it several years into the Covid-19 pandemic without catching the virus. Unfortunately, my time has come.

item.title: What is Genre?
item.description: A concept that is has been popping up in recent posts is genre. It’s not surprising, as genre is central not only to film–increasingly, the focus of this blog–but to rhetoric and writing studies, my academic home. But what is genre?

item.title: Superheroes: Ritual or Ideology?
item.description: I read something fascinating in Rick Altman’s book that I discussed in another recent post. He talked about two ways that critics tend to look at film’s social dimension. These are as ritual or as ideology.

item.title: Masculinity in Shane and Yojimbo
item.description: I’ve been going through some of my notes from a film genre class I took in graduate school. One week, we watched Shane and Yojimbo as cross-cultural examples of the western, which historically commingled with the samurai film in Japan.

item.title: Men (2022)
item.description: A few weeks ago, I went to see Alex Garland’s film Men. I really enjoyed, especially in the context of my growing interest in both film genre studies and the specific genre of horror.

item.title: Two Films on Catastrophe
item.description: Last night I watched Nicholas Ashe Bateman’s The Wanting Mare and Adam McKay’s Don’t Look Up. Each suggests a similar conclusion-in a senseless world, codependence is the only way to find meaning.

item.title: Memory, Document, Archive
item.description: By collecting and categorizing historical artifacts, archives deeply influence the historical record. But they exist in complicated institutional settings, and archivists can’t always have full control over how their archives present history. Researchers have to consider the archive less as a neutral place and more as a motivated and rhetorical construction.

item.title: What is New About New Media?
item.description: New media are better defined as media that challenge our existing conceptions of technology… even if the new media in question might be old.

item.title: Satoyama, Modernity, and Tradition in Japanese Anime
item.description: I’ve been reading scholarship about anime, its history, and how it deviates from animation in the United States. It’s frequently observed that tensions between tradition and modernity are often central to anime.

item.title: Academic Publishing and Research
item.description: Peer-Reviewed Publications (Single Author) “Disidentification and Documentation: LGBTQ Records as Emergent, Entangled Rhetoric.” Rhetoric Review, vol. 39, no. 2, March 2020. “Reading Our Disciplinary Future(s): Toward a Mobilities Framework for Agency.” Mobility Work in Composition, edited by Bruce Horner, Megan Faver Hartline, Ashanka Kumari, and Laura Matravers. •- “The World Outside the (Web)Text.” Making Future Matters, edited by Rick Wysocki and Mary P. Sheridan, Computers and Composition Digital Press/Utah State University Press, 2018.

item.title: Awards and Fellowships
item.description: Research Fellowships University Fellowship: Two-year course release for research awarded to most qualified doctoral students. University of Louisville (2016-2017, 2018-2019) HASTAC Scholars Program: A fellowship for scholars working at the intersection of technology, research, and teaching. Humanities, Arts, Science, and Technology Alliance and Collaboratory (2017-2019) Teaching Awards Writing Program Award for Teaching Excellence Faculty Favorite: Student Nomination for Excellence in Teaching. University of Louisville Delphi Center for Teaching and Learning (2015)

item.description: Soup Kitchen of Muncie Board Member: 2023-24 Chair of the Grants Committee: 2024 Member of the Grants Committee: 2023

item.title: Conditional Image Layouts in Hugo (Technical Article)
item.description: This post describes how to write conditional image layouts using Go and HTML for a Hugo site.

item.title: Editorial Work
item.description: Kairos: A Journal of Rhetoric, Technology, and Pedagogy Disputatio Section Co-Editor (2019-Present) Associate Editor (2016-2019) Making Future Matters Co-editor (with Mary P. Sheridan) of Making Future Matters, published by Computers and Composition Digital Press / Utah State University Press (2018) http://ccdigitalpress.org/makingfuturematters The Henry James Review Editorial Assistant The Miracle Monocle Website Design Editor (Issue 8, 2016)

item.title: Exporting ChatGPT Conversations (Tutorial)
item.description: I created this tutorial below for students to acknowledge their use of ChatGPT in writing, specifically by sharing relevant conversations when submitting assignments.

item.title: Little Ghost (Technical Documentation and Hugo Theme)
item.description: I developed Little Ghost, a simple theme for static site generator and content management framework Hugo. This project showcases my skills in both technical writing and web design.

item.title: Resume
item.description: Work Experience Ball State University Assistant Teaching Professor – English Department Muncie, IN August 2019 – Present Independently design and lead in-person, remote, and hybrid courses on technical and professional communication, digital writing, and academic research writing. Teach students best practices related to professional and technical communication, producing high quality documentation, content strategy, structured authoring, project management, and other industry-standard practices and tools (e.g., HTML5, Markdown, Git/GitHub). Develop and manage instructional assets, including instructional videos, online learning modules, and teacher-led lessons, using Ball State’s learning management system.
